skill.name: networkx
skill.description: Comprehensive toolkit for creating, analyzing, and visualizing complex networks and graphs in Python. Use when working with network/graph data structures, analyzing relationships between entities, computing graph algorithms (shortest paths, centrality, clustering), detecting communities, generating synthetic networks, or visualizing network topologies. Applicable to social networks, biological networks, transportation systems, citation networks, and any domain involving pairwise relationships.
skill.summary: Comprehensive toolkit for creating, analyzing, and visualizing complex networks and graphs in Python...
skill.author: K-Dense-AI

security_audit.summary: This is a documentation-only skill containing markdown files for the NetworkX Python library. All 495 static findings are FALSE POSITIVEs. The analyzer misinterprets markdown code fences as shell execution, NetworkX function names as cryptographic algorithms, and graph operations as system reconnaissance. No executable code exists. All URLs point to official NetworkX documentation.

content.user_title: Analyze and visualize complex networks with NetworkX
content.value_statement: Working with graph and network data requires specialized tools for creating structures, computing algorithms, and generating visualizations. This skill provides comprehensive access to NetworkX capabilities for social network analysis, biological pathway mapping, transportation optimization, and relationship modeling.
actual_capabilities: Create and manipulate graph data structures including undirected, directed, and multigraph variants
Compute graph algorithms such as shortest paths, centrality measures, and community detection
Generate synthetic networks using random, scale-free, and small-world models
Read and write graphs in multiple formats including GraphML, edge lists, and JSON
Visualize networks with customizable layouts using matplotlib and interactive libraries
limitations: Does not provide graph databases or persistent storage capabilities
Algorithms have O(n^2) or higher complexity for large networks; specialized libraries needed for massive graphs
Visualization limited to 2D representations; 3D networks require additional libraries

use_cases.title: Social network analysis
use_cases.description: Analyze relationship patterns, identify influencers, and detect communities in social media data

use_cases.title: Biological pathway mapping
use_cases.description: Model protein interactions, gene regulatory networks, and metabolic pathways

use_cases.title: Transportation optimization
use_cases.description: Optimize route planning, supply chain networks, and infrastructure design

prompt_templates.title: Basic graph creation
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a graph with 5 nodes and add edges between them to represent a basic network structure

prompt_templates.title: Path finding
prompt_templates.prompt: Find the shortest path between node A and node F in this graph and show the distance

prompt_templates.title: Centrality analysis
prompt_templates.prompt: Compute betweenness centrality for all nodes and identify which nodes are most critical

prompt_templates.title: Network generation
prompt_templates.prompt: Generate a Barabasi-Albert scale-free network with 100 nodes and 3 edges per new node

output_examples.input: Create a graph showing connections between team members
output: Graph created with 8 nodes representing team members
Edges added for direct reporting relationships
Nodes labeled with team member names
Drawn with circular layout for clarity

output_examples.input: Find the most central nodes in a citation network
output: Betweenness centrality computed for all 50 nodes
Top 5 most central papers identified with scores
Visualization shows node size by centrality value

best_practices: Set random seeds (seed=42) for reproducible random graph generation and force-directed layouts
Use sparse matrix formats and appropriate data structures when working with large networks
Save graphs in GraphML format to preserve node and edge attributes
anti_patterns: Using floating-point numbers as node identifiers can cause precision issues in algorithms
Loading entire large networks when only subgraph analysis is needed wastes memory
Forgetting to check graph connectivity before running algorithms that require connected graphs

faq.question: What graph types does NetworkX support?
faq.answer: NetworkX supports Graph (undirected), DiGraph (directed), MultiGraph (multiple edges undirected), and MultiDiGraph (multiple edges directed).

faq.question: How do I read a graph from a CSV file?
faq.answer: Use pandas to read the CSV, then nx.from_pandas_edgelist() with source, target, and optional edge attribute columns.

faq.question: What is the fastest way to find shortest paths?
faq.answer: Use nx.shortest_path() for single pairs. For all pairs, use nx.all_pairs_shortest_path() with an iterator to save memory.

faq.question: Can NetworkX handle directed acyclic graphs?
faq.answer: Yes, NetworkX handles DAGs with functions like nx.is_directed_acyclic_graph() and topological sorting via nx.topological_sort().

faq.question: How do I detect communities in a network?
faq.answer: Use community.greedy_modularity_communities(G) for modularity-based detection or other algorithms in networkx.algorithms.community.

faq.question: What visualization libraries work with NetworkX?
faq.answer: Matplotlib integrates natively. For interactive visualizations, use PyVis or Plotly with NetworkX graph objects.
